Violation.Message: The domain class sample.Book should define an equals(Object) method
The domain class sample.Book should define a toString() method

Rule.name: AddEmptyString
Rule.Description: Finds empty string literals which are being added. This is an inefficient way to convert any type to a String.

Rule.name: AssignCollectionSort
Rule.Description: The Collections.sort() method mutates the list and returns the list as a value. If you are assigning the result of sort() to a variable, then you probably don't realize that you're also modifying the original list as well. This is frequently the cause of subtle bugs.

Rule.name: AssignCollectionUnique
Rule.Description: The Collections.unique() method mutates the list and returns the list as a value. If you are assigning the result of unique() to a variable, then you probably don't realize that you're also modifying the original list as well. This is frequently the cause of subtle bugs.

Rule.name: AssignmentInConditional
Rule.Description: An assignment operator (=) was used in a conditional test. This is usually a typo, and the comparison operator (==) was intended.

Rule.name: BigDecimalInstantiation
Rule.Description: Checks for calls to the BigDecimal constructors that take a double parameter, which may result in an unexpected BigDecimal value.

Rule.name: BitwiseOperatorInConditional
Rule.Description: Checks for bitwise operations in conditionals, if you need to do a bitwise operation then it is best practive to extract a temp variable.

Rule.name: BooleanGetBoolean
Rule.Description: This rule catches usages of java.lang.Boolean.getBoolean(String) which reads a boolean from the System properties. It is often mistakenly used to attempt to read user input or parse a String into a boolean. It is a poor piece of API to use; replace it with System.properties['prop'].

Rule.name: BooleanMethodReturnsNull
Rule.Description: Method with Boolean return type returns explicit null. A method that returns either Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE or null is an accident waiting to happen. This method can be invoked as though it returned a value of type boolean, and the compiler will insert automatic unboxing of the Boolean value. If a null value is returned, this will result in a NullPointerException.

Rule.name: BrokenOddnessCheck
Rule.Description: The code uses x % 2 == 1 to check to see if a value is odd, but this won't work for negative numbers (e.g., (-5) % 2 == -1). If this code is intending to check for oddness, consider using x & 1 == 1, or x % 2 != 0.

Rule.name: CatchArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
Rule.Description: Check the size of the array before accessing an array element rather than catching ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

Rule.name: CatchError
Rule.Description: Catching Error is dangerous; it can catch exceptions such as ThreadDeath and OutOfMemoryError.

Rule.name: CatchException
Rule.Description: Catching Exception is often too broad or general. It should usually be restricted to framework or infrastructure code, rather than application code.

Rule.name: CatchIllegalMonitorStateException
Rule.Description: Dubious catching of IllegalMonitorStateException. IllegalMonitorStateException is generally only thrown in case of a design flaw in your code (calling wait or notify on an object you do not hold a lock on).

Rule.name: CatchIndexOutOfBoundsException
Rule.Description: Check that an index is valid before accessing an indexed element rather than catching IndexOutOfBoundsException.

Rule.name: CatchNullPointerException
Rule.Description: Catching NullPointerException is never appropriate. It should be avoided in the first place with proper null checking, and it can mask underlying errors.

Rule.name: CatchRuntimeException
Rule.Description: Catching RuntimeException is often too broad or general. It should usually be restricted to framework or infrastructure code, rather than application code.

Rule.name: CatchThrowable
Rule.Description: Catching Throwable is dangerous; it can catch exceptions such as ThreadDeath and OutOfMemoryError.

Rule.name: ClassForName
Rule.Description: Using Class.forName(...) is a common way to add dynamic behavior to a system. However, using this method can cause resource leaks because the classes can be pinned in memory for long periods of time.

Rule.name: CloneableWithoutClone
Rule.Description: A class that implements java.lang.Cloneable should define a clone() method.

Rule.name: ClosureAsLastMethodParameter
Rule.Description: If a method is called and the last parameter is an inline closure then it can be declared outside of the method call brackets.

Rule.name: CompareToWithoutComparable
Rule.Description: If you implement a compareTo method then you should also implement the Comparable interface. If you don't then you could possibly get an exception if the Groovy == operator is invoked on your object. This is an issue fixed in Groovy 1.8 but present in previous versions.

Rule.name: ComparisonOfTwoConstants
Rule.Description: Checks for expressions where a comparison operator or equals() or compareTo() is used to compare two constants to each other or two literals that contain only constant values, e.g.: 23 == 67, Boolean.FALSE != false, 0.17 <= 0.99, "abc" > "ddd", [a:1] <=> [a:2], [1,2].equals([3,4]) or [a:false, b:true].compareTo(['a':34.5, b:Boolean.TRUE], where x is a variable.

Rule.name: ComparisonWithSelf
Rule.Description: Checks for expressions where a comparison operator or equals() or compareTo() is used to compare a variable to itself, e.g.: x == x, x != x, x <=> x, x < x, x >= x, x.equals(x) or x.compareTo(x), where x is a variable.

Rule.name: ConfusingClassNamedException
Rule.Description: This class is not derived from another exception, but ends with 'Exception'. This will be confusing to users of this class.

Rule.name: ConfusingTernary
Rule.Description: In a ternary expression avoid negation in the test. For example, rephrase: "(x != y) ? diff : same" as: "(x == y) ? same : diff". Consistent use of this rule makes the code easier to read. Also, this resolves trivial ordering problems, such as "does the error case go first?" or "does the common case go first?".

Rule.name: ConsecutiveLiteralAppends
Rule.Description: Violations occur when method calls to append(Object) are chained together with literals as parameters. The chained calls can be joined into one invocation.

Rule.name: ConsecutiveStringConcatenation
Rule.Description: Catches concatenation of two string literals on the same line. These can safely by joined.

Rule.name: ConstantIfExpression
Rule.Description: Checks for if statements with a constant value for the if expression, such as true, false, null, or a literal constant value.

Rule.name: ConstantTernaryExpression
Rule.Description: Checks for ternary expressions with a constant value for the boolean expression, such as true, false, null, or a literal constant value.

Rule.name: DeadCode
Rule.Description: Dead code appears after a return statement or an exception is thrown. If code appears after one of these statements then it will never be executed and can be safely deleted.

Rule.name: DoubleNegative
Rule.Description: There is no point in using a double negative, it is always positive. For instance !!x can always be simplified to x. And !(!x) can as well.

Rule.name: DuplicateCaseStatement
Rule.Description: Check for duplicate case statements in a switch block, such as two equal integers or strings.

Rule.name: DuplicateImport
Rule.Description: Duplicate import statements are unnecessary.

Rule.name: DuplicateMapKey
Rule.Description: A map literal is created with duplicated key. The map entry will be overwritten.

Rule.name: DuplicateSetValue
Rule.Description: A Set literal is created with duplicate constant value. A set cannot contain two elements with the same value.

Rule.name: EmptyCatchBlock
Rule.Description: In most cases, exceptions should not be caught and ignored (swallowed).

Rule.name: EmptyElseBlock
Rule.Description: Empty else blocks are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EmptyFinallyBlock
Rule.Description: Empty finally blocks are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EmptyForStatement
Rule.Description: Empty for statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EmptyIfStatement
Rule.Description: Empty if statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EmptyInstanceInitializer
Rule.Description: An empty class instance initializer was found. It is safe to remove it.

Rule.name: EmptyMethod
Rule.Description: A method was found without an implementation. If the method is overriding or implementing a parent method, then mark it with the @Override annotation.

Rule.name: EmptyStaticInitializer
Rule.Description: An empty static initializer was found. It is safe to remove it.

Rule.name: EmptySwitchStatement
Rule.Description: Empty switch statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EmptySynchronizedStatement
Rule.Description: Empty synchronized statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EmptyTryBlock
Rule.Description: Empty try blocks are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EmptyWhileStatement
Rule.Description: Empty while statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

Rule.name: EqualsAndHashCode
Rule.Description: If either the equals(Object) or the hashCode() methods are overridden within a class, then both must be overridden.

Rule.name: EqualsOverloaded
Rule.Description: The class has an equals method, but the parameter of the method is not of type Object. It is not overriding equals but instead overloading it.

Rule.name: ExceptionExtendsError
Rule.Description: Errors are system exceptions. Do not extend them.

Rule.name: ExplicitArrayListInstantiation
Rule.Description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a ArrayList using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new ArrayList()" as "[]", which creates the same object.

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToAndMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the and(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the & operator. A groovier way to express this: a.and(b) is this: a & b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToCompareToMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the compareTo(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the <=>, >, >=, <, and <= operators. A groovier way to express this: a.compareTo(b) is this: a <=> b, or using the other operators.

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToDivMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the div(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the / operator. A groovier way to express this: a.div(b) is this: a / b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToEqualsMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the equals(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the == or != operator. A groovier way to express this: a.equals(b) is this: a == b and a groovier way to express : !a.equals(b) is : a != b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToGetAtMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the getAt(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the [] index operator. A groovier way to express this: a.getAt(b) is this: a[b]

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToLeftShiftMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the leftShift(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the << operator. A groovier way to express this: a.leftShift(b) is this: a << b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToMinusMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the minus(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the - operator. A groovier way to express this: a.minus(b) is this: a - b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToModMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the mod(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the % operator. A groovier way to express this: a.mod(b) is this: a % b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToMultiplyMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the minus(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the * operator. A groovier way to express this: a.multiply(b) is this: a * b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToOrMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the or(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the | operator. A groovier way to express this: a.or(b) is this: a | b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToPlusMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the plus(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the + operator. A groovier way to express this: a.plus(b) is this: a + b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToPowerMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the power(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the ** operator. A groovier way to express this: a.power(b) is this: a ** b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToRightShiftMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the rightShift(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the >> operator. A groovier way to express this: a.rightShift(b) is this: a >> b

Rule.name: ExplicitCallToXorMethod
Rule.Description: This rule detects when the xor(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the ^ operator. A groovier way to express this: a.xor(b) is this: a ^ b

Rule.name: ExplicitGarbageCollection
Rule.Description: Calls to System.gc(), Runtime.getRuntime().gc(), and System.runFinalization() are not advised. Code should have the same behavior whether the garbage collection is disabled using the option -Xdisableexplicitgc or not. Moreover, "modern" jvms do a very good job handling garbage collections. If memory usage issues unrelated to memory leaks develop within an application, it should be dealt with JVM options rather than within the code itself.

Rule.name: ExplicitHashMapInstantiation
Rule.Description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a HashMap using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new HashMap()" as "[:]", which creates the same object.

Rule.name: ExplicitHashSetInstantiation
Rule.Description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a HashSet using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new HashSet()" as "[] as Set", which creates the same object.

Rule.name: ExplicitLinkedHashMapInstantiation
Rule.Description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a LinkedHashMap using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new LinkedHashMap()" as "[:]", which creates the same object.

Rule.name: ExplicitLinkedListInstantiation
Rule.Description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a LinkedList using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new LinkedList()" as "[] as Queue", which creates the same object.

Rule.name: ExplicitStackInstantiation
Rule.Description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a Stack using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new Stack()" as "[] as Stack", which creates the same object.

Rule.name: ExplicitTreeSetInstantiation
Rule.Description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a TreeSet using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new TreeSet()" as "[] as SortedSet", which creates the same object.

Rule.name: ForLoopShouldBeWhileLoop
Rule.Description: A for loop without an init and update statement can be simplified to a while loop.

Rule.name: GStringAsMapKey
Rule.Description: A GString should not be used as a map key since its hashcode is not guaranteed to be stable. Consider calling key.toString().

Rule.name: GrailsDomainHasEquals
Rule.Description: Checks that Grails domain classes redefine equals().

Rule.name: GrailsDomainHasToString
Rule.Description: Checks that Grails domain classes redefine toString()

Rule.name: GrailsPublicControllerMethod
Rule.Description: Checks for public methods on Grails controller classes. Static methods are ignored.

Rule.name: GrailsServletContextReference
Rule.Description: Checks for references to the servletContext object from within Grails controller and taglib classes.

Rule.name: GrailsStatelessService
Rule.Description: Checks for fields on Grails service classes. Grails service classes are singletons, by default, and so they should be reentrant and typically stateless. The ignoreFieldNames property (dataSource,scope,sessionFactory,transactional,*Service) specifies one or more field names that should be ignored. The ignoreFieldTypes property (null) specifies one or more field type names that should be ignored. Both can optionally contain wildcard characters ('*' or '?').

Rule.name: GroovyLangImmutable
Rule.Description: The groovy.lang.Immutable annotation has been deprecated and replaced by groovy.transform.Immutable. Do not use the Immutable in groovy.lang.

Rule.name: HardCodedWindowsFileSeparator
Rule.Description: This rule finds usages of a Windows file separator within the constructor call of a File object. It is better to use the Unix file separator or use the File.separator constant.

Rule.name: HardcodedWindowsRootDirectory
Rule.Description: This rule find cases where a File object is constructed with a windows-based path. This is not portable, and using the File.listRoots() method is a better alternative.

Rule.name: ImportFromSamePackage
Rule.Description: An import of a class that is within the same package is unnecessary.

Rule.name: ImportFromSunPackages
Rule.Description: Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages. These packages are not portable and are likely to change.

Rule.name: IntegerGetInteger
Rule.Description: This rule catches usages of java.lang.Integer.getInteger(String, ...) which reads an Integer from the System properties. It is often mistakenly used to attempt to read user input or parse a String into an Integer. It is a poor piece of API to use; replace it with System.properties['prop'].

Rule.name: InvertedIfElse
Rule.Description: An inverted if-else statement is one in which there is a single if statement with a single else branch and the boolean test of the if is negated. For instance "if (!x) false else true". It is usually clearer to write this as "if (x) true else false".

Rule.name: MisorderedStaticImports
Rule.Description: Static imports should never be declared after nonstatic imports.

Rule.name: MissingNewInThrowStatement
Rule.Description: A common Groovy mistake when throwing exceptions is to forget the new keyword. For instance, "throw RuntimeException()" instead of "throw new RuntimeException()". If the error path is not unit tested then the production system will throw a Method Missing exception and hide the root cause. This rule finds constructs like "throw RuntimeException()" that look like a new keyword was meant to be used but forgotten.

Rule.name: RandomDoubleCoercedToZero
Rule.Description: The Math.random() method returns a double result greater than or equal to 0.0 and less than 1.0. If you coerce this result into an Integer or int, then it is coerced to zero. Casting the result to int, or assigning it to an int field is probably a bug.

Rule.name: RemoveAllOnSelf
Rule.Description: Don't use removeAll to clear a collection. If you want to remove all elements from a collection c, use c.clear, not c.removeAll(c). Calling c.removeAll(c) to clear a collection is less clear, susceptible to errors from typos, less efficient and for some collections, might throw a ConcurrentModificationException.

Rule.name: ReturnFromFinallyBlock
Rule.Description: Returning from a finally block is confusing and can hide the original exception.

Rule.name: ReturnNullFromCatchBlock
Rule.Description: Returning null from a catch block often masks errors and requires the client to handle error codes. In some coding styles this is discouraged.

Rule.name: ReturnsNullInsteadOfEmptyArray
Rule.Description: Consider returning a zero length array rather than null. It is often a better design to return a length zero array rather than a null reference to indicate that there are no results (i.e., an empty list of results). This way, no explicit check for null is needed by clients of the method.

Rule.name: ReturnsNullInsteadOfEmptyCollection
Rule.Description: Consider returning a zero length collection rather than null. It is often a better design to return a length zero collection rather than a null reference to indicate that there are no results (i.e., an empty list of results). This way, no explicit check for null is needed by clients of the method.

Rule.name: SimpleDateFormatMissingLocale
Rule.Description: Be sure to specify a Locale when creating a new instance of SimpleDateFormat; the class is locale-sensitive. If you instantiate SimpleDateFormat without a Locale parameter, it will format the date and time according to the default Locale. Both the pattern and the Locale determine the format. For the same pattern, SimpleDateFormat may format a date and time differently if the Locale varies.

Rule.name: SwallowThreadDeath
Rule.Description: Checks for code that catches ThreadDeath without re-throwing it.

Rule.name: ThrowError
Rule.Description: Checks for throwing an instance of java.lang.Error.

Rule.name: ThrowException
Rule.Description: Checks for throwing an instance of java.lang.Exception.

Rule.name: ThrowExceptionFromFinallyBlock
Rule.Description: Throwing an exception from a finally block is confusing and can hide the original exception.

Rule.name: ThrowNullPointerException
Rule.Description: Checks for throwing an instance of java.lang.NullPointerException.

Rule.name: ThrowRuntimeException
Rule.Description: Checks for throwing an instance of java.lang.RuntimeException.

Rule.name: ThrowThrowable
Rule.Description: Checks for throwing an instance of java.lang.Throwable.

Rule.name: UnnecessaryGroovyImport
Rule.Description: A Groovy file does not need to include an import for classes from java.lang, java.util, java.io, java.net, groovy.lang and groovy.util, as well as the classes java.math.BigDecimal and java.math.BigInteger.

Rule.name: UnusedArray
Rule.Description: Checks for array allocations that are not assigned or used, unless it is the last statement within a block.

Rule.name: UnusedImport
Rule.Description: Imports for a class that is never referenced within the source file is unnecessary.

Rule.name: UnusedObject
Rule.Description: Checks for object allocations that are not assigned or used, unless it is the last statement within a block.

Rule.name: UnusedPrivateField
Rule.Description: Checks for private fields that are not referenced within the same class.

Rule.name: UnusedPrivateMethod
Rule.Description: Checks for private methods that are not referenced within the same class.

Rule.name: UnusedPrivateMethodParameter
Rule.Description: Checks for parameters to private methods that are not referenced within the method body.

Rule.name: UnusedVariable
Rule.Description: Checks for variables that are never referenced.
